titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Camilo José Vergara Collection of Urban Church Ephemera
Vergara (Camilo José) Collection of Urban Church Ephemera
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday April 22, 2019 at 22:00

did.unittitle: Camilo José Vergara Collection of Urban Church Ephemera
did.abstract: This collection contains church bulletins, brochures, event notices, newletters, fans, and other ephemera documenting urban churches in America,primarily dating from 2000-2004. These materials shed light on the weekly activities of churches, their pastors and leaders, worship services, and outreach efforts. They provide a fascinating snapshot of religion in urban America.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Camilo José Vergara Collection of Urban Church Ephemera (RG 234), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The documentation in this collection was collected by Camilo José Vergara in connection with his book, How the Other Half Worships (New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press, 2005) and in subsequent visits to urban churches throughout the United States. In the introduction to his book, Vergara wrote: " How the Other Half Worships has its roots in the late 1970s, when I began photographing the built environment of poor, minority communities in cities across the United States. Churches were such a prevalent feature of the urban landscape that I quickly understood them to be crucial to my project, and a separate study of them began to develop. The subject of this study inevitably grew beyond the church buildings themselves to include socioeconomic conditions and religious practices that shape these churches and give them meaning."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains church bulletins, brochures, event notices, newletters, fans, and other ephemera documenting urban churches in America. The activities of small and large churches from across the country are documented, with particular emphasis on the New York City area. These materials shed light on the weekly activities of churches, their pastors and leaders, worship services, and outreach efforts. They provide a fascinating snapshot of religion in urban America.
